Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Membrane Nanodomains--Prediction and Detection

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to predict and detect the formation of lipid nanodomains in giant unilamellar vesicles (GUVs). Lipid nanodomains are believed to play a significant role in a number of critical cellular processes, including replication processes in enveloped viruses such as bird flu and HIV and signaling mechanisms underlying pathological conditions such as cancer. The research approach involves three main activities:
1) developing the first imaging modality suitable to detect and characterize the formation of nanodomains; 2) developing multiscale models and numerical methodologies for nanoraft simulation; and 3) identifying the conditions needed for the formation of nanodomains and image them in GUVs. An important byproduct of these activities concerns addressing the question of whether or not such nanodomains can form at all in the absence of auxiliary stabilizing agents such as proteins.
If successful, the results of this research will provide an imaging modality that can be transferred to bioscientists to observe and detect, and eventually help control, the emergence of rafts in cells. Such knowledge might be used, for example, to guide the development of treatment schemes for cancer involving the control of growth factors and other membrane signaling molecules. Results from the research activities will be disseminated by providing the microscope techniques to manufacturers, making the computer codes freely available online to other scientists and engineers, and by providing images and animations to teachers and science museums. Undergraduate and graduate engineering students will be trained in the experimental, theoretical, and computational techniques involved in this research through a system of lab rotations

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was a collaboration between researchers at Duke University and Washington University in St. Louis, studying the formation of small domains on the surfaces of Giant Unilamellar Vesicles (GUVs), which are model systems for cells.  Work at Duke University focused on the development of new theoretical approaches and simulation tools to study these types of phenomena with a level of detail and resolution that is not possible experimentally.  These simulation results in turn helped guide additional experimental measurements at Washington University in St. Louis.  

The intellectual merit of this work stems from the development of a continuum chemo-mechanical  to numerically simulate the dynamics of microdomain evolution on the deforming surface of GUVs. The model focused on the regime of vesicle dynamics where shape deformation occurs on a much faster time scale than does species transport, as suggested by several experiments. Shape changes were assumed to be instantaneous, simulating a condition in which the viscosity of the vesicle and that of the host medium are negligible. The chemo-mechanical model was cast in a phase-field framework, and  the variational form of the resulting fourth order nonlinear equations was discretized using a spline-based finite-element method. 

Several two-dimensional and axisymmetric numerical examples were used to illustrate the coupling of species transport to vesicle shape changes, resulting in effects that include curvature-dependent domain sorting and line tension dominated shape changes. Particularly, the influence of the postulated difference in time scales between species transport and shape change was exhibited using a two-dimensional example.   The contrast is expected to be more prominent in the presence of line tension. Shape changes dominated by line tension reduce the length of interface.  Three-dimensional simulations were developed to clearlyillustrate the effects of line tension. Simulations in three dimensions with hierarchical mesh refinement schemes for the spline-based finite-element discretization were developed to make these simulations accurate and efficient.  

The broader impacts of this work are associated with the fact that our research results will enable bioscientists to observe and detect, and eventually help control, the emergence of rafts in cells.  Such knowledge might be used, for example, to guide the development of treatment schemes for cancer involving the control of growth factors and other membrane signaling molecules.  Results from the research activities were disseminated by providing the microscope techniques to manufacturers, making the computer codes freely available online to other scientists and engineers, and by providing images and animations to teachers and science museums.  Undergraduate and graduate engineering students were trained in the experimental, theoretical, and computational techniques involved in this research through a system of lab rotations.
